I've read (mostly) the thread about this, and while I don't personnally need
asserts count, I think it's an interesting discusssion and could be the base
for a "user story" for JUnit :

"Have a way to easily plug-in / plug-out assert counting code"

It could be the first step towards pluggability in junit that would allow
the core to stay clean and simple but yet allow a lot of features / add-ons
to integrate and play nicely with each others. It's a simple enough thing (I
think) that it should not be impossible to do.

I'm I way off? Isn't this kind of thinking "The XP way"TM ?
please give opinions on this.

mathieu

----- Original Message -----
From: Robert Watkins
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2001 7:41 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts


Shane Duan wrote:
> Plus, I am sure that all the XP developers would strongly
> disagree with the comment here.  The closest way I can think
> of is to name the method as test_NeedImplement() but it sure
> looks weird.
>
> Mind if I ask why exactly do you want a empty test method
> there?  What is the difference if you just add the method later?

XP developers will say nothing of the sort. If the comment is the simplest
thing that works, go for it. FWIW, I would use the method name to tell me
what I'm meant to be testing.

As to why: it's a placeholder so you don't forget it. Consider it similar to
a PostIt note.

Robert.
